children.name: 5. Assessment: Medical experts’ feedback on results
Introduction
children.content: Medical experts hold an essential role in this research methodology from its earliest stages. For this reason, their feedback was collected at multiple points and through different modalities. To evaluate the medical knowledge emerging from the workshop activities, a dedicated expert validation process was carried out. Medical professionals with expertise in UTIs were invited to review a selection of workshop outcomes, including written narratives, artefact descriptions, and excerpts from conversation transcripts. Their task was to assess the clarity, quality, and relevance of the health-related insights produced by participants. As outlined in the “Assessment aims and methods” section (3.3.8), each expert received a personalised document containing compiled excerpts and summaries of participant contributions. This material allowed them to provide written comments before taking part in an online semi-structured interview. These interviews offered an opportunity to explore their reflections in greater depth and to situate their observations within clinical reasoning. The involvement of medical experts served a dual purpose. First, it supported the verification of the clinical significance of the insights generated in the workshops. Second, it helped determine whether participants introduced new forms of knowledge, alternative terminology, or distinct ways of communicating symptoms and experiences of UTIs. This assessment not only validates the findings but also examines the potential of personal narratives and embodied representations to contribute to more patient-centred conversations in healthcare.

children.name: 5.1 Interview modalities and interviewees
Introduction
children.content:
After being contacted via email and invited to participate to 45-minute
online interviews, each expert received a personalised document
containing the highlights from the workshop analysis. These documents
included excerpts from transcripts, summaries of participant
contributions, and descriptions of artefacts. Experts were asked to read
the material before the interview, add written comments, and reflect on
both the clinical relevance and linguistic or narrative dimensions of
the content.

A total of 12 healthcare professionals were interviewed. They have been
selected because of their expertise in infectious diseases, UTIs, and
antibiotic resistance. A couple of them do not work on these topics but
adopt narrative methods to follow patients during the cure. Some of the
experts specifically work with UTI patients, while others do not engage
directly with patients but work in research settings. These experts are
professionals I met during my research and members of the SPEARHEAD
consortium. I prioritised female experts to address the asymmetry in
data collection and interpretation, as the data discussed pertains to
women’s physical and mental conditions. However, I also included male
experts whose profiles were especially relevant to the topic or
methodology of my research. I interviewed 3 male and 9 female experts,
ensuring that women’s perspectives were central in interpreting and
providing feedback on the findings.

Medical expert interviewees are identified with the letter ME to
distinguish them from workshop participants (P). Below is a list of all
the experts’ profiles involved in this phase of the assessment, with
gender specified in brackets because of the reason above:

- ME1 (female): Senior researcher and lecturer in Biomedical Ethics at
  the master's in medicine in the Faculty of Biomedical Sciences of the
  Università della Svizzera italiana. Previously at the Oncology
  Institute of the Italian Switzerland (IOSI), focusing on ethics,
  communication, and technology in health contexts (female);

<!-- -->

- ME2 (female): Project manager at the University Hospital in Basel. She
  holds a PhD in clinical research and currently works on antibiotic
  stewardship. Works closely with patients and doctors in hospitals
  (female);

- ME3 (female): Head of Clinic in the Infectious Diseases Department at
  CHUV and University of Lausanne (UNIL). She holds specialist titles in
  Internal Medicine (2021) and Infectious Diseases (2022). Previously
  worked in Hospital Hygiene, Prevention, and Infection Control at CHUV;

- ME4 (female): Pharmacist with a PhD at the Swiss Centre for Antibiotic
  Resistance. She performs epidemiological analyses, works at the
  University Hospital of Basel and the geriatric hospital in Basel, and
  supports physicians and nurses in optimizing treatments as a clinical
  pharmacist;

- ME5 (female): Intern in clinical research medicine in infectious
  diseases at Geneva Hospital, graduated from Geneva Medical School in
  2022, focusing on epidemiology and supporting ME12 in the UTI clinic;

- ME6 (female): Infectious disease physician with experience in
  infectious diseases for 7 years and in UTIs specifically for 1 year,
  assisting with the opening of a UTI clinic;

- ME7 (female): Senior researcher at the University of Basel and
  professor in pediatric infectious diseases at City St. Georges, UK.
  Trained as a pediatrician;

- ME8 (female): Medical anthropologist and senior research fellow at the
  Bern University of Applied Sciences, deputy head of the "Psychosocial
  Health" research unit. Her research focuses on organ transplants,
  palliative care, gender medicine, and expertise in healthcare, with a
  growing emphasis on interdisciplinary and participatory approaches;

- ME9 (male): Head of the hospital pharmacy at University Hospital in
  Basel. He leads a research group in Pharmacoepidemiology. Pharmacist
  by training, with extensive experience in community pharmacy, drug
  safety research, and patient-related pharmacy services;

- ME10 (male): MD-PhD candidate at the Institute of Microbiology,
  Lausanne University Hospital. Specialises in antimicrobial resistance
  research;

- ME11 (male): Professor of Surgery at USI and Chief of the
  Hepatobiliary Center in Lugano and specialises in liver, pancreas, and
  bile duct surgery, with research in surgical techniques and outcomes,
  and an interest in narrative medicine;

- ME12 (female): Infectious disease specialist and professor at the
  University Hospital of Geneva. She works on general infectious
  diseases with a subspecialty in UTIs. She manages an outpatient UTI
  clinic and provides inpatient consultations for complex UTI cases;

Online interviews of fourtyfive minutes have been conducted on Teams.
The questions that guided the semi-structured interview are the
following:

- What is the first thing that impressed you the most (if any) - that
  emerged from the analysis?

- Is there anything in the material that you find unclear, inaccurate,
  or that you would disagree with?

- Do the analysis reveal any new symptoms or relevant insights related
  to UTIs or women’s intimate infections? If so, what are they?

- How do these new insights relate to the current medical knowledge
  available on these symptoms or diseases?

- Did you notice any unusual or unexpected words used by participants to
  describe symptoms or the disease, compared to those commonly found in
  clinical literature or patient reports?

- In your opinion, do these alternative descriptions help improve the
  understanding of the symptoms? If yes, in what way?

Half of the interviewees also provided comments directly on the Word
file shared with them, following the optional request. These comments
were reviewed during the interviews and incorporated into the
preliminary analysis. Two participants had not read the document prior
to the interview, so at the beginning of the conversation, I provided a
summary of the activity and an overview of the main findings to guide
the discussion.

children.name: 5.1.1 Analysis of medical expert interviews
children.content: The interviews were transcribed and coded for analysis. The analysis shows a clear gap between clinical diagnostic routines and the way patients actually experience their illness. According to the experts, this misalignment complicates both diagnostic processes and the delivery of care. At the same time, their reflections point to the potential of design-led, narrative, and material-based approaches to mediate between these perspectives and support more comprehensive forms of understanding. To explore these findings, the chapter is structured around four main themes. The first theme, “The diagnostic challenge”, details the core clinical ambiguities in symptom identification, progression, and the profound lack of a shared language between patients and clinicians. The second theme, “The lived experience”, moves beyond physical symptoms to explore the significant psycho-emotional burden of UTIs and the patient's journey from confusion toward self-management and empowerment. The third theme, “Bridging the gap”, examines how the design-led methods used in this research, specifically narrative practices and the use of physical artefacts, were assessed by experts as powerful tools for facilitating richer communication and shared meaning-making. Finally, the fourth theme, “Methodological reflections”, offers a critical evaluation of this novel approach, considering its practical limitations, risks of misinterpretation, and its future potential within clinical and research contexts. The complete analysis and coding table is available in the Appendix. Fig. 20 - Coding table for the thematic analysis of results on UTIs.

children.name: Theme 1: The diagnostic challenge. Ambiguity in symptom identification and expression
Misunderstandings, misattributions, and unclear symptoms
children.content:
Across the interviews, experts consistently noted that patients often
struggle to correctly identify and differentiate UTIs from other
conditions. This difficulty appeared even in basic terminology, as one
expert recalled a participant who “described incontinence as urge”
(ME10), and extended to broader diagnostic uncertainty, where experts
observed “\[how\] confused patients are about their own symptoms… a kind
of collective thinking that helps them identify” (ME5). First-time
episodes were described as particularly challenging, since “if a woman
has experienced the first time UTI, she doesn’t really know what to
expect. If somebody had a second or third, she probably will react much
quicker” (ME9).

Cultural explanations frequently contributed to misattributions.
Patients often linked UTIs to cold exposure, reporting beliefs such as
“when you are sitting on the cold place, that is this factor for
developing UTI” (ME3) or “cystitis can come after sitting on a cold
chair… we often hear that from patients as well” (ME6). Although
clinicians dismissed these explanations as unscientific, they
acknowledged how persistent and widespread such beliefs remain.

Experts also described ambiguous or unusual symptom expressions that
blurred clinical categories. Examples included references to “the
swollen, the swelling… not often with UTIs” (ME5) or “swollen stomach…
not something I learned” (ME10), which were considered diagnostically
unclear: “swollen stomach… not clear if feeling or physical examination”
(ME10). Reliance on sensory cues could also mislead, as seen in comments
about “urines that have a false smell… studies show you get better
without antibiotics” (ME6). Misattributions further extended to overlaps
with other infections, especially mycosis, where “symptoms can overlap…
need lab work to distinguish” (ME6).

These examples illustrate how subjective framings, cultural beliefs, and
imprecise terminology complicate diagnostic clarity. Even when harmless,
such narratives can delay or obscure accurate medical assessment.

children.name: Symptom variability, specificity, and progression
children.content:
Clinicians emphasised that UTIs do not follow a uniform pattern of
symptoms but instead present wide variability. Burning during urination
was described as the most common complaint: “most of the time it was a
burning sensation when going to the toilet” (ME9). However, experts
stressed that this is not universal: “Not everyone has the burning… some
people have different manifestations” (ME12). Patients also expressed
pain in diverse ways, referring to “punching pain, pulsing pain… burning
pain, stinging pain” (ME10), underscoring the importance of recognising
qualitative differences rather than relying on generic descriptors.

Indicators of severity and progression were considered especially
meaningful. Clinicians noted how certain patterns signal escalation,
such as “radiation into the kidneys, back pain… speaks for ascending
infection” (ME9), or “vomiting… probably when you have pyelonephritis…
not the same as cystitis” (ME3). Haematuria, or blood in the urine, was
consistently identified as a red flag (ME6). Clinicians also
distinguished clearly between “two kinds… simple cystitis…
pyelonephritis… very different disease” (ME12), highlighting the
importance of differentiating lower from upper urinary tract infections.

Despite these distinctions, symptoms frequently overlapped with those of
other intimate conditions. Vaginal infections, for example, were
contrasted through discharge and odour (ME5), yet patients rarely
recognised these cues as distinct. Experts also pointed out that
variability extends to individual interpretation: “manifestation can be
quite individual… some interpreted it this way, others that way” (ME9).
This variability reinforced the need for clinicians to assess
combinations of symptoms and how they develop over time, rather than
relying on isolated indicators.

children.name: The vocabulary gap: the struggle for a shared language
children.content:
Experts consistently identified communication as a central challenge in
diagnosing UTIs. While some clinicians argued that most women “really
know their symptoms” and that “there’s very rarely problems in the
communication” (ME6), others pointed to substantial gaps between medical
terminology and the language used by patients. As one expert observed,
there is a “discrepancy between medical terms and terms \[from people\]”
(ME4), and another described expressions such as “intimate infections”
as “not precise… scientifically you would have to be precise” (ME2).
These misalignments create confusion not only during clinical encounters
but also within research activities, where ensuring that “participants
really understand what a symptom means” was considered essential (ME4).

The lack of a shared vocabulary extended across linguistic and cultural
contexts. ME8 emphasised that word choice carries different connotations
across languages: “…what kind of words are used for what and what are
the connotations… and what are the connotations in the different
languages?” (ME8). ME7 further questioned whether shared words reliably
convey shared sensory experiences: “…do you have a stinging sensation…
what I mean by that in terms of quality is the same as the patient? I
just don’t know that that’s always the case… we’re very bad at finding a
shared language” (ME7).

These vocabulary gaps had concrete implications for diagnosis. Several
clinicians stressed that accurate assessment depends on eliciting
precise descriptions: “the doctor really needs to understand if the pain
is like a burning sensation or more like an electric shock… materials
gave space to describe more precisely” (ME1). Other experts noted that
verbal accounts alone may be insufficient, particularly in vulnerable
groups such as elderly patients with dementia who “can’t really talk”
(ME12). Some clinicians used structured questioning, such as “do you
have burning pain? … do you have to wake up at night to urinate…” (ME6),
while others preferred open-ended conversation that allowed patients to
elaborate freely (ME12). These practices are typical of UTI-specific
clinical settings where both doctors and patients are familiar with the
condition and its recurrent nature.

Overall, the interviews reveal that language is not a neutral medium but
an active site where meaning can be lost, negotiated, or co-constructed.
Without efforts to bridge linguistic and cultural gaps, diagnostic
processes risk remaining ambiguous and inconsistent. Experts therefore
stressed the importance of integrating precise yet accessible
vocabularies, fostering shared understanding of symptom-related terms,
and complementing verbal reports with contextual cues such as timelines,
patterns, or material tools to improve diagnostic reliability.

children.name: Theme 2: The lived experience of the psycho-emotional and relational burden of UTIs
Anxiety, fear, and shame: The unspoken symptoms
children.content:
Psychological and emotional aspects emerged as integral to how patients
perceive and manage UTIs, even though they are often excluded from
clinical frameworks. Experts described how anxiety, fear, and shame
shape patient experiences. ME5 remarked that “people don’t talk about
the anxiety and the fear behind having infections enough” (ME5), while
ME12 illustrated the sense of vulnerability through a metaphor: “there’s
a sword hanging over me… symptoms could start anytime” (ME12).

Emotions were also linked to recognition of early cues, as ME5 observed:
“very early patients… know even though there isn’t a pain… something’s
wrong” (ME5). However, shame could obstruct awareness, as in the case of
a patient who “thought it was because she was having too much sex… she
didn’t know it was something that can occur” (ME10).

Clinicians often framed these emotional responses as secondary rather
than symptomatic. ME6 described anxiety as “secondary to the infection”
(ME6), and ME3 commented that such psychological reactions “will never
be found in a book” yet still have “a huge impact” (ME3). Panic and
incontinence were likewise acknowledged as psychological reactions
(ME2). Despite this medical framing, many experts acknowledged that the
emotional burden of UTIs remains underestimated in practice. Recurrent
infections, often dismissed as minor, are for patients “a real big
thing” (ME3), and the burden varies significantly across individuals
(ME10).

children.name: The journey to literacy: From confusion to competence
children.content:
Participants’ engagement in workshops revealed a transformative journey
from uncertainty to informed self-recognition. The creative process of
externalising symptoms provided the occasion to reflect and straight
bodily awareness. As one expert observed, the setting itself “was
functioning as an intervention… I believe it also happened through the
participants’ own awareness” (ME1). By expressing symptoms through
materials and sharing them with others, participants deepened their
understanding: “Reporting it to others and having to explain it through
these materials… it was possible to collect data” (ME1). Over time, this
reflective practice led to “a more sophisticated elaboration… to
describe their symptoms more precisely” (ME1).

This evolution in self-knowledge directly supported clinical
interactions. Participants began to “understand better what happens…
which is a good step… also to explain it to the doctor” (ME10).
Recognition and validation were crucial in this process, counteracting
experiences of dismissal: “Very validating already… these are women who
often are told you don’t have anything” (ME12). Such acknowledgement
fostered confidence and empowered individuals to take an active role in
their care.

Initially, however, many participants lacked basic symptom literacy.
Discomfort was frequently dismissed as insignificant: “This itching,
this pain… you don’t necessarily put it on something medical or disease”
(ME2). For first-time patients, this uncertainty was particularly
pronounced, especially in contexts like pregnancy, where “there is so
much you don’t understand about your body… symptoms of infection is new”
(ME2).

Developing literacy required the ability to interpret bodily signals:
“You need a sort of like basic knowledge to recognise symptoms… some
others are maybe just a normal and not normal condition, but something
that you do not recognise as symptoms” (ME8). This learning process was
relational and iterative. External aids, such as thermometers or
self-monitoring devices, supported recognition (ME8), while peer
exchanges and expert input played a central role: “Diagnosing knowledge
is always relational” (ME8). Repeated exposure helped participants
refine their descriptions and build timeline awareness, which experts
described as diagnostically significant: “Some patients reported this
timeline of the symptomatics… one clue often that the person has
recurrent infections” (ME10).

Recurrent episodes served as powerful teachers. Initial confusion gave
way to rapid recognition: “If a woman has experienced the first time
UTI, she doesn't really know what to expect. If… had a second or third,
she probably will react much, much quicker” (ME9). Repeated cycles of
diagnosis and treatment reinforced experiential expertise: “Learning,
diagnosing, treating, learning. Having it again… after the second, third
or fourth time, you're probably specific” (ME9). Accurate early
diagnosis was crucial, enabling participants to build a reliable
knowledge base for future management: “Doctor makes a proper diagnosis…
this happens two or three times, then it will most likely just be… the
right thing in the future” (ME9). Over time, some progressed toward
semi-autonomous care, supported by immediate access to medication (ME9).
Preventive practices, such as post-coital hygiene, were also adopted:
“Cleanliness… after sexual intercourse… recommended to avoid UTIs and it
works quite well” (ME10).

Altogether, these insights describe a progression from confusion to
competence, where experiential learning, validation, and relational
support converge to strengthen participants’ ability to recognise,
articulate, and manage their symptoms with increasing clarity and
confidence.

children.name: Empowerment through education and relational care
children.content:
Education emerged as a central driver of patient empowerment, enabling
individuals to participate actively in their care while supporting
responsible antibiotic use. Experts stressed that informed patients
complement, rather than replace, clinical expertise: “…the idea is not
to cut the doctor out… but rather… enable the patient-citizen to support
the doctor” (ME1). Through enhanced understanding, patients could
communicate more effectively, allowing clinicians to “intervene with
treatment in a more targeted and effective way” (ME1).

Antibiotic stewardship was a consistent objective across interviews.
Improving awareness was seen as key to reducing unnecessary
prescriptions: “Help decrease the antibiotic prescription… clearly we
need that” (ME3). Better comprehension of disease mechanisms altered
patient expectations, reducing demands for antibiotics: “Improving and
understanding about the disease… has an effect on antibiotic use. …
Patient don’t think, oh, I need an antibiotic” (ME4).

Patients echoed this sentiment, recognising the value of reconsidering
automatic requests for medication: “I shouldn't just ask for an
antibiotic… it could be something completely different…” (ME9). For many
clinicians, simple information-sharing proved transformative: “A lot of
what I do is just informing, and it's actually hugely impactful. … So it
helps to save antibiotics” (ME12).

Beyond information transfer, relational practices created the conditions
necessary for this transformation to take place. Safe spaces for
dialogue allowed patients to express uncertainties, seek clarification,
and develop confidence: “…provided space to share their feelings…
methods… to talk about insecurities and feelings… and clarify some
doubts… a space where you can ask your questions… and a space where you
have time” (ME4). Narrative approaches were particularly effective in
reinforcing individuality and trust: “The narrative approach is
indispensable to build a relationship… in which he feels safe… The
biography is nothing else than the validation of the individuality of a
patient…” (ME11). Recognising patients as people, rather than cases,
fostered engagement: “If you are interested in knowing who he is, beyond
his illness, ah, another relationship is established…” (ME11).

Such relational and educational practices are fundamental as they
sustained awareness, encouraged responsible self-management, and
positioned patients as informed partners in care, supporting both
personal wellbeing and public health goals.

children.name: Theme 3: Facilitating meaning-making through narrative and physicalization
Materials as communicative tools: Eliciting nuanced vocabularies
children.content:
Across the interviews, medical experts consistently described physical
materials as powerful facilitators of communication, capable of
eliciting richer and more precise accounts of symptoms. ME1 emphasised
that the very act of explaining material choices produced meaningful
insight: “…even just to justify why they were putting a ball on top of a
polystyrene triangle… it was possible, through the material that
requires explanation, to collect data” (ME1). Materials encouraged
participants to extend their vocabularies, sometimes beyond medical
terminology, since “…the material greatly helped bring out or find new
vocabularies, non-scientific vocabularies” (ME1).

Experts highlighted how objects supported layered forms of expression
that combined physical, emotional, and psychological dimensions. ME2
explained that patients often needed “different materials to express
herself because it was different feelings and different… they could not
be presented by one material” (ME2). Artefacts frequently acquired
symbolic meaning: upward shapes represented relief, while necklace-like
forms suggested heaviness (ME2). Such combinations made abstract
sensations tangible and helped participants articulate nuances that
might remain inaccessible through words alone.

Sensory and affective qualities reinforced this expressivity. ME8
described how polystyrene’s tactile and auditory properties resonated
with embodied discomfort: “…some people, really. Get like a big feeling
when you touch it or when you even like connect it… thinking about how I
recall the sensation of a UTI like this. It's just like this is
discomfort” (ME8). These observations suggest that material properties
can bridge internal sensations and communicable forms, allowing patients
to externalise experiences that are otherwise difficult to express.

Materials also supported communication of both qualitative and
quantitative aspects of symptoms. ME10 noted that participants conveyed
intensity and magnitude through the size and number of elements they
selected: “…the different persons found how to qualify qualitatively the
symptoms, but also… quantitatively because… the size of the forms or the
numbers of the different forms they used had a meaning” (ME10). ME7
further observed that objects have the capacity to describe not only
intensity, as in conventional visual analogue scales, but also quality:
“…if you had… 9 objects, you could capture intensity, but you could also
capture quality” (ME7).

This extended expressive capacity suggests that workshop materials
functioned as communicative tools rather than simple modelling elements.
As ME1 noted, they enabled “a more sophisticated elaboration… to
describe their symptoms more precisely” (ME1). Experts suggested that
expanding the material palette, such as introducing metallic or
temperature-sensitive elements, could enhance this potential.

Despite these strengths, experts raised concerns about subjectivity and
interpretation. ME8 emphasised that “…the use of materials… is very
subjective… what happens in the workshop where people then discuss these
very subjective interpretations of their sensations…” (ME8),
highlighting the need for facilitation that mediates divergent readings.
ME10 warned of “interpretation bias” when objects lack contextual
explanation: “…if you do not have this person that explains you what
exactly it means… then you have the risk of interpretation bias” (ME10).
His surprise at fur being used to express fever underscored the risk of
intuitive mismatch: “…fur is for me something smooth, comfortable… not
very intuitive to use something comfortable to qualify something
disagreeable, like fever” (ME10).

Some experts questioned whether materials were always necessary. ME4
acknowledged the value of the discussion space they created but doubted
their indispensability: “I could imagine that's good to have a room to
discuss such questions and feelings… but I'm not sure if it's needed
that work with material” (ME4). Nonetheless, several experts contrasted
material-based communication favourably with conventional scales,
pointing out that objects support more nuanced expression than purely
numeric or verbal measures.

Overall, these expert insights portray materials as communicative tools
that broaden expressive possibilities and help participants articulate
embodied experiences with greater nuance. At the same time, they
underscore the need for contextual explanation and critical facilitation
to mitigate subjective interpretation. Materials enrich communication by
enabling non-scientific vocabularies, sensory associations, and
multimodal representation, ultimately expanding the repertoire available
to patients for describing intimate health experiences.

children.name: Metaphors and analogies as bridges to understanding
children.content:
Metaphors and analogies emerge as indispensable tools for articulating
sensations that defy straightforward description. ME5 described how
metaphors make subjective pain intelligible: “In the case of urinary
tract infections, it will often be… urinating needles like you’re
feeling. And so these are things that you give them examples just
because it is hard to describe it. It also in a way that will make
medical professionals understand” (ME5). For men with prostate
infections, analogies helped overcome discomfort and inexperience:
“…does it feel like a hot potato in your pelvis? …oh yeah, kind of… it
just helps them” (ME5).

Patients themselves generated potent imagery. ME12 recounted how one
woman described “an elephant… sitting on her bladder… a lot of pressure,
this sense of this heaviness” (ME12), while a child compared their
symptoms to “the moment before sneezing” (ME12). Metaphors also captured
the emotional weight of illness, as with the “sword hanging over me” to
describe fear of recurrence (ME12).

These figurative expressions provide common ground between subjective
experience and medical interpretation. They translate sensations into
recognisable referents, bridging the gap between bodily feeling and
shared understanding.

children.name: Collective sense-making and validation in peer dialogue
children.content:
The workshop provided an opportunity for collective reflection, where
participants compared and refined their descriptions through shared
dialogue. ME5 noted how such exchanges enabled patients to clarify and
own their experiences: “…how confused patients are about their own
symptoms… it’s a kind of collective thinking that helps them identify
what the symptoms are exactly. And to put words on them better, you
know” (ME5).

This dynamic validates individual sensations while offering shared
reference points. As ME5 explained, “it’s very helpful to have somebody
say something and then you can say if yes or no, that is the same… it’s
easier… especially like to describe it in a way that people will
understand it” (ME5). Yet, collective processes also introduced risks.
ME5 warned that patients might inadvertently adopt each other’s terms,
even when clinically inappropriate: “…two people are talking about pain,
but it’s not pain in the same place and it’s not the same type of pain”
(ME5).

children.name: Theme 4: Methodological reflections on potential, pitfalls, and pathways to practice
Interpretation, limits, and risks
children.content:
While experts acknowledged the expressive value of materials, they
repeatedly cautioned against the risks of misinterpretation. Artefacts
were seen as highly dependent on participants’ explanations, functioning
less as stand-alone representations and more as prompts that required
verbal contextualisation. As ME1 emphasised, “…something that absolutely
needed an explanation, otherwise it could not be understood…” (ME1), and
ME10 warned that “…you really need the presentation of the one that did
the artefact because if you do not have it you are going to
misinterpret… you give free room to interpretation, then you have the
risk of interpretation bias.” (ME10).

Concerns also emerged regarding clinical translation. ME5 questioned
whether metaphorical objects could be reliably mapped onto medical
categories: “…if a patient’s like oh, it feels it reminds me very much
of this and they take out a wooden sphere then like the doctors may not
know what \[it\] that means…” (ME5). ME8 highlighted both subjectivity
and intersubjectivity in this interpretive process: “…how you connect
and associate with… the sensations of your symptoms… is very subjective…
and also then the intersubjectivity in between, like what happens in the
workshop where people then discuss these very subjective
interpretations…” (ME8).

Some experts doubted whether the approach aligned with clinical
priorities or helped address unmet needs. ME11 stated, “…the character
of the pain has not helped me. So, since your approach is the
materialization of this character, I would not necessarily have chosen
that direction to respond to an unmet need.” (ME11). ME6 and ME8 also
expressed reservations about its necessity and clarity.

However, several experts recognised value beyond clinical diagnosis. ME2
pointed to the method’s potential in public engagement: “…the output, at
least in forms of the material and the pictures of what the participant
did… could be very funny to use for a discussion or campaign… posters or
postcards…” (ME2). ME10 linked the interpretive nature of artefact
reading to familiar clinical practices, noting that “…it’s a challenge…
but it’s more or less the same in clinical life when you… see the body
language… it’s also interpretation… you need both.” (ME10).

Collectively, these reflections show that while material artefacts can
deepen expression and enrich communication, they must be carefully
contextualised, accompanied by explanation, and aligned with intended
use to minimise misinterpretation and maximise their value.

children.name: Clinical applicability and transferability
children.content:
Expert opinions diverged on whether material-based methods could be
integrated into routine clinical practice. ME1 raised the central issue
of transferability, asking, “…I asked myself how then to transfer
somewhere all that you have learned regarding the use of materials”
(ME1). They imagined possible adaptations, such as compact kits or
labelled tools, but also acknowledged the difficulty of translation into
clinical settings: “…maybe it could be moved into the doctor’s office,
where the doctor has a tool in hand, whether your labels or a material…”
(ME1).

Other experts were more sceptical about feasibility. ME5 pointed to
structural constraints that limit expressive methods in clinical
encounters, noting that “…consultations usually last maximum 15 minutes…
patients are not asked to describe it… they’ll be asked to answer
questions” (ME5). ME9 similarly regarded the method as primarily
reflective rather than clinically actionable: “…I wouldn’t say this is
something that you can really apply maybe… in a doctor's office or in a
pharmacy… It’s more like again reflecting the individual sensation”
(ME9).

Despite these reservations, several experts recognised potential value
in specific contexts. ME12 suggested integrating textures into
anatomical models to support communication in chronic or recurrent
conditions: “…it might be useful to create a material using your…
different textures… in the shape of a bladder so that they can say,
yeah, this is how my bladder feels like” (ME12). Such applications
indicate that while direct implementation in general practice is
unlikely, adapted material-based approaches may serve as useful tools in
targeted areas such as chronic pain management, patient education, or
awareness campaigns.

children.name: Representativeness and generalisability
children.content:
Experts reflected critically on the representativeness of workshop
participants, raising concerns about inclusivity and generalisability.
ME1 explicitly questioned: “I always ask myself the question, who are we
leaving out in the research?”, pointing to the methodological challenge
of ensuring findings do not disproportionately reflect certain groups.

From a clinical perspective, ME2 noted discrepancies between
participants and typical patient populations: “My worries would be as a
clinician… I don't recognise those I know from the clinic or from the
literature necessarily in your participants… mostly women around
pregnancy… elderly women…” (ME2). ME6 similarly emphasised that most
participants seemed to be first-time patients, contrasting with
recurrent or complex cases often encountered in practice: “Usually it's
people who don't have regular infections… maybe who experience their
first UTIs… and elderly also have…” (ME6).

children.name: The value for patients and future research potential
children.content:
Experts consistently highlighted the value of material-based methods for
patients, particularly in providing validation and encouraging
reflection. The simple act of dedicating time to explore symptoms
through tangible means was described as profoundly positive: “…just the
act of taking the time of thinking about this with them, of creating,
you know, making available these materials, it's very validating
already… these are women who often are told you don’t have anything…”
(ME12).

Transforming often-dismissed sensations into concrete, shareable
artefacts legitimised patient experiences and offers a basis for
dialogue. The participatory setting also creates a safe and constructive
environment for discussion. As one expert noted, it “…provided space to
share their feelings… to talk about insecurities and feelings and
symptoms… and I read also that the participant like that there's an
expert, so they could clarify some doubts” (ME4). Clinician presence
helped to ensure that discussions remained accurate and supportive, “to
actually clarify and add… medical insights in the discussion” (ME3).
Beyond validation, the process actively strengthened patients’ ability
to articulate their experiences: “…maybe if patients… think about it
more as well to be able to say no, it’s this or not this” (ME5).
Engagement extended beyond cognitive benefits, fostering positive
emotional involvement: “…they really like it… I could take these things
out and they can… open them…” (ME12).

Alongside these immediate benefits, experts recognised the broader
research and diagnostic potential of material-based methods. ME4
identified the approach as “a really new method… I could imagine that
would be a good method also for children to learn about… to describe
symptoms” (ME4), while ME9 characterised it as “very special… women try
to conceptualise and to symbolise their symptoms which is I think quite
a creative way to do it…” (ME9). Some experts saw opportunities for
systematic investigation of symptom expression, where recurring patterns
in materials might indicate meaningful clusters: “…if you basically…
find that certain groups of signs or symptoms… ever tend to result in
them using similar images… or textures… then that would be really
something very interesting as an observation” (ME7). This would require
empirical validation to establish clinical relevance: “…if you can
really validate that… say you know this is 80% correct whenever people
combine this and this… then you could really have a sort of a set for
these situations…” (ME9).

children.name: 5.1.2 Limitations of the medical expert interviews as assessment method
children.content:
The use of medical expert interviews as an assessment method, while
crucial for validating and contextualising the workshop findings, also
presents limitations that ultimately strengthen the research by
highlighting areas for refinement. The expert sample, primarily drawn
from my professional network and the SPEARHEAD consortium, carries a
risk of partiality and reduces exposure to more critical, external
perspectives. Feedback from the panel further indicated that the
workshop participants, often first-time or particularly patients, did
not fully represent the complexity of recurrent UTI populations. This
reflects both the methodological evolution of the study, which expanded
from an initial narrow focus on UTIs to include women’s intimate
infections, and the inherent challenges of recruiting participants for
sensitive topics.

The assessment relied on preliminary findings shared as a written
document. While the results were intentionally presented descriptively
to avoid influencing responses, they lacked the immediacy of raw data,
which would have been too demanding for participants to process within
the interview format. Furthermore, the structure of short, remote
interviews constrained deep engagement with the artefacts themselves,
and the physical and practical nature of the workshops proved difficult
to capture in written form alone. This underscores the need for future
assessments to incorporate direct interaction with artefacts and the
processes behind them. Considering the participatory environment of the
methodology, a promising next step would be to involve both patients and
medical experts not only in data collection and assessment but also in
the interpretation of results, fostering a more collaborative and
integrated evaluative process.

children.name: 5.1.3 Conclusions from the assessment
children.content:
The analysis of expert interviews underscores the dual contribution of
this study while revealing productive tensions that enrich its
implications. From a medical knowledge perspective, experts recognised
the variability of symptom expression, the overlap with other intimate
infections, and the importance of distinguishing recurrent from
first-time experiences in supporting patient awareness. They confirmed
that laboratory testing remains indispensable but acknowledged that
richer descriptions, enabled by metaphors, contrasts, and material
proxies, can capture nuances of quality and intensity details often
absent from biomedical discourse. From a methodological perspective, the
interviews affirmed that the workshop can function as a communicative
and empowering practices. Experts recognised the value of this approch
as a supplement to existing methods, such as pain scales, enhancing
patient validation and supporting forms of collaborative, situated
dialogue that complement clinical reasoning.

The discussions also surfaced several productive tensions that highlight
the challenges of integrating patient experience with clinical
perspectives. Some experts, like ME6, reported rarely encountering
communication barriers, while others, such as ME12 and ME2, emphasised
persistent misrecognition, stigma, and under-treatment, underlining the
need for innovative communicative tools. Disagreement also emerged
around perceived triggers: ME3 dismissed cold exposure as clinically
unfounded, whereas ME6 noted its frequent mention by patients, pointing
to a gap between biomedical evidence and lived accounts. Anxiety
likewise divided perspectives, framed by patients as a core symptom and
by clinicians like ME3, ME6, and ME12 as a secondary impact, yet both
sides acknowledged its clinical relevance. Finally, tension between
breadth and focus emerged: some, like ME3 and ME2, cautioned that overly
broad inclusion of symptoms and metaphors could undermine clinical
validity, while others valued the comprehensiveness for capturing the
complexity of women’s experiences.

These insights reinforce the dual aim of the research, which are to
expand medical understanding of UTIs through lived experience and to
demonstrate how participatory data physicalization can improve symptom
perception and communication. The experts also highlight the need to
refine the method by concentrating on recurrent UTIs and by
incorporating information on both the intensity and the quality of
experiences, helping to address the communication gaps identified in the
initial review of the literature (Chapter 2).
